awd_titl_txt: Broadband Two-Photon Absorption Spectroscopy for High-Repetition-Rate Lasers
awd_abstract_narration:
Broadband Two-Photon Absorption Spectroscopy for High-Repetition Rate Lasers 

With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Christopher Elles and his group at the University of Kansas are working to develop and implement new laser-based methods to measure and characterize the properties of molecules. The activation of molecules using intense laser pulses has important applications in many research fields, ranging from microscopic imaging of biological samples to the development of high-density optical data storage media. However, the best methods currently available for these applications are only accessible to research groups with specialized technical expertise, which are not necessarily the groups who make the materials. Working with both graduate and undergraduate students, Professor Elles is developing new techniques and instrumentation that will make these sophisticated measurements more widely accessible to the research community. By simplifying the process for characterizing the properties of laser-activated molecules, this work enables more rapid development of new compounds and new technologies, including diagnostic and therapeutic biomedical applications. The project also includes an integrated educational outreach program to help current and future high school science teachers develop new teaching materials that incorporate key concepts from contemporary research and address the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS).

The research team is developing more widely accessible methods for measuring broadband two-photon absorption (2PA) spectra using high-repetition rate femtosecond lasers. Current methods to measure 2PA spectra, including z-scan and two-photon excited fluorescence (2PEF), are limited to single-wavelength measurements and are not easily implemented by groups that do not specialize in nonlinear spectroscopy. To overcome these limitations, the group is working to design an integrated, one-box spectrometer that can be coupled with any existing femtosecond pulsed laser system to quickly and easily obtain accurate 2PA spectra, providing a valuable new tool for molecular spectroscopy. The team is working to develop new capabilities that include accurate absolute 2PA cross-sections, single-shot data acquisition, and on-the-fly imaging of 2PA spectra.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The selective activation of molecules using a process called two-photon absorption has become widely used in technologically advanced applications ranging from biological imaging and photodynamic therapy to 3D data storage and 3D printing. The two-photon absorption process uses intense laser pulses to excite molecules by inducing the simultaneous absorption of two photons that would not otherwise be absorbed. Some of the advantages of this approach include highly localized excitation that occurs only in the focal volume of the laser (smaller than the volume of a blood cell), the ability to excite target molecules without damaging the surrounding material due to indiscriminate UV absorption, and deeper penetration into tissue or other materials compared with irradiation that leads to one-photon excitation by the same target molecules. 

The development of new and existing applications that take advantage of the two-photon absorption process will require more efficient and more versatile target molecules, which, in turn, depends on the development of new methods for spectroscopic characterization and screening of candidate compounds. In order to address these challenges, the goal of this project was the development of several new experimental approaches that will make broadband two-photon absorption (BB-2PA) spectroscopy easier to use and more widely accessible to non-experts. Key outcomes include the development of an internal referencing technique that uses a background signal from the solvent to provide very accurate measurements of the two-photon absorption strength of a molecule, a single-shot measurement technique that provides a substantial reduction of the time required for measuring high-quality spectra while also significantly simplifying the acquisition and analysis of broadband two-photon absorption spectra, and the measurement of high-quality reference standards that can be used for comparison with other measurements. The measurements of reference standards and other molecules reveal new insights that are possible using this simplified and quantitatively accurate approach and also highlight significant improvements in the quality of spectra compared with the point-by-point (single-wavelength) scanning approaches that are used in traditional methods.

Collectively, these advancements make the technique easier to use and represent a first step toward making the approach more widely available by groups who design and synthesize molecules, but do not necessarily have training in the advanced laser techniques that are generally required for measuring the two-photon absorption properties of the molecules they make. The value of the new measurement approach was demonstrated through research collaborations that were made possible by this award. Such collaborative efforts highlight the broader impacts of the work based on the new insights that are now more easily accessible to synthetic research groups. New spectroscopic insights enable the design and implementation of new dye molecules, and therefore have a direct impact on the development of new applications using molecules with desirable functionality and large two-photon activity and therefore will enable new advances in biological imaging, targeted medical treatments, and other applications that require highly localized and highly selective activation of molecules in complex samples. Other important outcomes of the work include advanced technical training for graduate and undergraduate research students and the development of new teaching materials related to two-photon absorption spectroscopy and related applications. 

 


Last Modified: 05/28/2024
Modified by: Christopher G Elles
